measured_by: Inverted Encoding Model (IEM) decoding of M/EEG signals obtained with a spatial attention localizer task
justification: The article explains that "this relies on a dedicated functional localizer task and an encoding model that is inverted to estimate the locus of attentional allocation on a single-trial basis from the pattern of M/EEG signals across the scalp"—describing how covert spatial attention is tracked via the IEM analysis of M/EEG data.

measured_by: Beta-band lateralization in parietal and premotor cortices recorded with M/EEG
justification: It notes that "well-established M/EEG signals that track the state of decision accumulators (e.g., the beta-band lateralization in parietal and pre-motor cortices)" can be used, indicating this neural signature is the measure for the accumulator construct.

The text states that "Empirical findings suggest that people are risk-averse in description-based lotteries"—implying risk preference is assessed by observing choices in explicitly described lotteries.

The same sentence contrasts this with being "risk (variance)-seeking when value information is experienced sequentially," referring to experience-based tasks (e.g., bandit paradigms) as the measurement context for risk preference.
